topics.title: 1. Introduction to Python
topics.content:
Theory:
Python is a high-level, interpreted, and easy-to-learn programming language.

Example:
print("Hello, Python!")

topics.title: 2. Setting Up Python
topics.content:
Theory:
To run Python, install Python from python.org and check the version.

Example:
Check version using:
python --version

topics.title: 3. Basic Syntax
topics.content:
Theory:
Python uses indentation instead of braces.

Example:
if True:
    print("Indented block")

topics.title: 4. Variables and Data Types
topics.content:
Theory:
Python supports int, float, string, boolean, list, tuple, dict.

Example:
age = 20
price = 99.9
name = "Parvati"

topics.title: 5. Operators
topics.content:
Theory:
Python supports arithmetic, logical, comparison, and assignment operators.

Example:
a = 10
b = 5
print(a + b)

topics.title: 6. Conditional Statements
topics.content:
Theory:
Use if, elif, and else for decision making.

Example:
marks = 80
if marks > 75:
    print("Distinction")

topics.title: 7. Loops in Python
topics.content:
Theory:
Python supports for and while loops.

Example:
for i in range(5):
    print(i)

topics.title: 8. Functions
topics.content:
Theory:
Functions are reusable blocks created using def.

Example:
def add(a, b):
    return a + b

topics.title: 9. Lists
topics.content:
Theory:
Lists are ordered, changeable, and allow duplicate values.

Example:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "orange"]
print(fruits[0])

topics.title: 10. Tuples
topics.content:
Theory:
Tuples are ordered but immutable.

Example:
coords = (10, 20)
print(coords)

topics.title: 11. Dictionaries
topics.content:
Theory:
Dictionaries store data in key-value pairs.

Example:
student = {"name": "Parvati", "age": 20}
print(student["name"])

topics.title: 12. Sets
topics.content:
Theory:
Sets store unique values and are unordered.

Example:
nums = {1, 2, 3, 3}
print(nums)

topics.title: 13. String Methods
topics.content:
Theory:
Python contains many useful built-in string functions.

Example:
text = "hello"
print(text.upper())

topics.title: 14. File Handling
topics.content:
Theory:
Python can read and write files using open().

Example:
with open("demo.txt", "w") as f:
    f.write("Hello World")

topics.title: 15. Exception Handling
topics.content:
Theory:
Errors are handled using try-except blocks.

Example:
try:
    print(10/0)
except:
    print("Error occurred")

topics.title: 16. Object-Oriented Programming
17. Modules and Packages
topics.content:
Theory:
Modules allow code reusability; packages group multiple modules.

Example:
import math
print(math.sqrt(16))

topics.title: 18. List Comprehension
topics.content:
Theory:
A concise way to create lists.

Example:
squares = [x*x for x in range(5)]
print(squares)

topics.title: 19. Lambda Functions
topics.content:
Theory:
Anonymous functions created using lambda keyword.

Example:
add = lambda a, b: a + b
print(add(2, 3))

topics.title: 20. Python Libraries
topics.content:
Theory:
Popular libraries include NumPy, Pandas, Matplotlib, Flask, Django.

Example:
import random
print(random.randint(1, 10))
